content:
ばいりつ〔倍率〕
〈名〉Magnifying power; magnification

content.content: 五百倍率の顕微鏡
a microscope of 500 diameters magnifying power―of 500 magnifications

はいりつする〔廃立する〕
〈自他動〉To dispose of the crown (at one's pleasure); to enthrone and dethrone (the sovereign)

content:
はいりょ〔配慮〕
〈名〉Concern; solicitude; interest

content.content: 種々ご配慮にあずかりましてありがとう存じます
I am obliged to you for your solicitude in my behalf―interesting yourself in my welfare.
本件に関し特別の御配慮をわずらわしたく候
I request you will particularly interest yourself in the matter.

はいりょうけい〔肺量計〕
〈名〉The spirometer; the pulmometer

content:
はいりょうする〔拝領する〕
〈他動〉To receive as a gift (from a superior)

content.content: これは親父が君公から拝領した時計だ
This watch was a gift to my father from his liege-lord.

content:
はいる〔這入る、入る〕
〈自動〉
1. To enter (a house or a room); to go in, go into (a house); to come in, come into (a room); to walk in, into (a room):(どうかして入る)to get in, get into (a house):(ちょっと入る)to step in, into (a room)

content.content: お入り
Come in!―Walk in!―Step in!
入ってよろしいか
(君のいるところへ)May I come in?―(あの室へ)―May I go in?
中へ入って後を締めろ
Come in, and shut the door after you.
そこは雨が降るからこちらへお入り
Come in out of the wet!
いっぱいでどうしても入れなかった
The house was full, and I could not get in.
入れと言うから入った
I entered at his bidding.
彼は入れともなんとも言わないのに入った
He entered unbidden.
お勉強のお邪魔をしてはと思って入らない
I do not enter lest I should disturb you in your studies.
人を追い出して後へ入って澄ましている
He ousted me, and quietly stepped into my shoes.
教室へ傘を持って入ってはいかん
You must not bring your umbrella into the class-room.
試験場へ本を持って入ってはいかん
You must not take a book into the examination room.

content: 2. To enter (a school); to enter (the army or the navy)

content.content: 昨年高等学校へ入れば入れたのだ
I could have entered the high school last year.
大学へ入る
to matriculate
会社へ入る
to enter a company's service
病院へ入る
to go to (the) hospital
料理屋へ入る
to go to a restaurant
実業界へ入る
to go into business
彼は実業界に入っている
He is in business.

content: 3. To join (a party or a society)

content.content: 彼はメゾジスト教会へ入った
He has joined the Methodist Church―associated himself with the Methodists.
仲間に入る
to join a party
君も仲間に入らないか
Won't you join in?―make one (of the party)?
三十人及第して僕もその仲間に入っている
Thirty have passed, myself among the rest.
穴へ入る
to enter a hole―(死んでなら)―sink into the grave
穴があったら入りたいようだった
I felt like sinking into the floor―I was ready to sink into the ground.
床に入る
to get into bed
湯に入る
to take a bath―have a bath―(英米では)―have one's tub
僕は毎日朝湯に入る
I have my morning bath every day―(英国風に言えば)―I regularly have my morning tub.
河へ入る、海へ入る
to bathe in the river―bathe in the sea
井戸へ入る
(あやまってなら)to fall down the well―(わざとなら)―throw oneself into the well
子どもが井戸へ入った
A child fell down the well.
わたしゃ井戸へ入って死んでしまいます
I will drown myself in the well.
娯楽館へ入る
to obtain admission into a hall of amusement
十時後は入れぬ
You will not be admitted―You can not gain admission―after ten.
この名刺を持って行けばいつでも入れる
This card will gain you admission.
この札を持って行けばただで入れる
This ticket will gain you free admission―This ticket entitles the holder to be admitted free (of charge).
泥棒に入る
to break into a house―(泥棒の符牒では)―crack a crib
泥棒が入る
A burglar breaks into a house.
昨夜僕の家へ泥棒が入った
Our house was broken into―We had our house broken into―last night.
強盗に入る
to make a forcible entry into a house
強盗が入る
A robber makes a forcible entry into a house―enters a house by force.
近所の家へ強盗が入った
There has been a robbery in a neighbouring house.
毒が身体へ入る
Poison enters into the system.
鉄砲玉が股へ入った
The bullet entered into the thigh―embedded itself in the thigh.
何か目に入った
Something has got into my eye.
芥が目に入る
Dust gets into the eye.
目に入ってもどうでもない
You may keep it in your eye (and be none the worse for it).
耳に入る
to reach one's ears―come to one's ears―come to one's knowledge
このことが親父の耳に入ってはたいへんだ
The affair must not reach my father's ears.
間へ入る
to go between two parties―mediate between two parties―interpose between two parties―intervene between two parties―act as go-between―act as mediator
何の部類に入る
to fall under the head of―come under the head of...
八犬伝は伝奇小説の部類に入る
The “Hakkenden” falls under the head of romances.
玄関から入る
to enter at the front door
裏口から入る
to enter at the back entrance
泥棒がどこから入ったか
How did the burglar enter the house?
この窓から入った
He entered by this window.［注意］「から入る」の「から」は普通の入口ならば“at,”特別の入口ならば“by”を用いる。
右の耳から入って左の耳から出てしまう
“Go in at one ear, come out at the other.”
明かりは窓から入る
Light comes in at the window―(他動詞構文にすれば)―The window lets in the light―The window admits the light.
この徳利はいくら入るか
How much does this bottle hold?
四合入る
It holds a quart.
この鞄とあの鞄とどちらが多く入るか
Which of these trunks holds the most?
この箱ならずいぶん入る
This box holds a great deal.
この教室は千人入る
This room can seat a thousand―This room is capable of seating a thousand.
生徒が多くて教室に入りきれぬ
There are so many students that the room can not hold them all.
あの病院には患者が五百人入れる
The hospital can accommodate 500 patients.
何人入れる場所がある
There is room for so many.
まだ入れますか
Is there room for more?
もう一人入れます
There is room for one more.
皆入るだけの場所が無い
There is not room enough for all.
いっぱいでもう入る隙が無い
The house is full, and there is no room for more.
船が入る
A steamer puts into port―comes in.
船が明朝入ります
The boat will be in tomorrow morning―The boat is due tomorrow morning.
金が入る
Money comes in.
金がいくら入るか
What income have you?
あの地位はいくら入るか
What does his position bring him in?
月千円入る
It brings him in 1000 yen a month.
金がどんどん入る
Money flows in―pours in.
入るより出る方が多い
More goes out than comes in―The outgoings exceed the incomings.
入る金は出る方へ取られてしまう
The expenses swallows up the receipts.
何月に入る
A month begins.
今月に入ってから一日も好天気が無い
We have not had a single fine day since the beginning of this month.
雨季に入る
The rainy season sets in.
もう寒に入った
The cold season has set in.
孔が小さくて手が入らない
I can not get my hand into the hole―I can not get my hand through the hole―The hole is too small to admit my hand.
靴が小さくて足が入らない
The shoes are so small that I can not get them on―get (my feet) into them.
手袋が小さくて手が入らない
The gloves are so small that I can not get them on―get my hands into them.
この薬に何が入るか
What enters into the composition of this medicine?
阿片が入る
Opium enters into its composition.
金貨には銅が入る
Copper enters into the composition of gold coins―Gold coins contain copper.
日本料理には砂糖が入る
There is sugar in Japanese dishe―They put sugar in Japanese dishes―Japanese dishes contain sugar.
日本の菓子には砂糖が入り過ぎる
There is too much sugar in Japanese confectionery―Japanese confectionery contains too much sugar.
財布に金が入っている
There is some money in the purse―The purse has some money in it.
財布に金がいっぱい入っている
The purse is full of money.
芝居に人がいっぱい入っている
The house is full (of people)―packed (with people)―closely packed―filled to overflowing―crowded to suffocation.
雑費は勘定に入っている
The expenses are included in the account―The account includes the expenses.
その村は本道から少し入ったところだ
The village is a little way off the road.
銀座から入った横丁だ
It is a lane off the Ginza.
義太夫は声に力が入る
One strains the voice in reciting Gidayu―Gidayu strains the voice.
よく入る腹だ
You have a capacious stomach―You have a wolf in your stomach.
あの家へもう人が入った
The house is occupied.

はいれ〔歯入れ〕
〈名〉(=足駄の歯入れ)A clog-mender

はいれつ〔配列〕
〈名〉Arrangement; disposition:(=する) to arrange (articles); to range, dispose (troops); to marshal (facts, etc.)

content:
はう〔這う〕
〈自動〉To creep; to crawl

content.content: 毛虫がワサワサ這う
Worms crawl.
昆虫が這う
Insects creep.
蛇がニョロニョロ這う
A snake crawls on its belly―goes on its belly.
幼児がノタノタ這う、四つに這う
A baby crawls (on all fours).
蔓が這う
A vine creeps―climbs―(地を這う)―trails.
這って歩く
to creep along―crawl about

はうた〔端唄〕
〈名〉A short love song (sung to the samisen accompaniment)

content:
はえ〔蠅〕
〈名〉The fly; the (common) house-fly

content.content: 蠅がうるさい(追えども来たる夏の蠅)
The flies buzz about my ears.
食物に蠅がたかる
The flies swarm about food.
砂糖に蠅がたかる
Flies settle on sugar.
臭いものには蠅がたかる
Where there is filth, there swarm the flies.
蠅は病毒の媒介をする
The fly is a medium for the dissemination of disease-germs.
蠅を払う
to drive away the flies
馬が尾を振って蠅を払う
The horse whisks the flies away.
アゴで蠅を払う
to be debilitated by excess of sexual indulgence
己が頭の蠅を追え
Mind your own business!

content:
はえぎわ〔生え際〕
〈名〉The roots of the hair

content.content: 額の生えぎわがそろっている
The roots of her hair are well-pencilled.

content:
はえそろう〔生え揃う〕
〈自動〉To complete the number of growths

content.content: 雛はまだ羽毛が生え揃わない
The chicks are not yet fully fledged.
子どもはまだ歯が生え揃わない
The child has not cut all its teeth yet.
禿げたのじゃない、毛がまだ生え揃わないのだ
He has not grown bald; his hair has not grown yet.

はえちょう〔蠅帳〕
〈名〉A meat-safe

content:
はえとり〔蠅取り〕
〈名〉A fly-flap; a fly-trap

content.content: 蠅取紙
fly-paper
蠅取粉
fly-powder
蠅取草
the fly-trap
蠅取燕
the fly-catcher

はえぬき〔生え抜き〕
〈形〉(An Edokko) born and bred

はえばえしい〔栄え栄えしい〕
〈形〉Showy; bright; conspicuous

content:
はえる〔栄える〕
〈自動〉To be bright; to be conspicuous

content.content: 紺地に金は栄える
Gold shows well on blue―Blue sets off gold.
君は洋服が栄える
Foreign clothes set you off to advantage.
栄える色
a bright colour
栄えない色
a dull colour
栄える姿
a conspicuous figure
栄えない役
an inconspicuous character

content:
はえる〔生える〕
〈自動〉
1. (=生えている)to grow

content.content: 毛が生える
Hair grows.
頭に毛が生える
Hair grows on the head―The head is covered with hair.
あの人は胸に毛が生えている
Hair grows on his breast―He has a hairy breast.
アイヌ人は全身に毛が生えている
The Aino is covered with hair all over.
中学生に毛のはえたくらいのものだ
They are just above the middle-school grade―something better than middle-school students.
草が生える
Grass grows―Weeds grow.
草はひとりで生える
Weeds grow of themselves.
庭に草がいっぱい生えている
Weeds overgrow the garden―The garden is overgrown with weeds.
木が生える
Trees grow.
山に木が生えている
Trees grow on the mountain―The mountain is wooded.
パンに黴が生えている
The bread is mouldy―covered with mould.
靴に黴が生えている
The shoes are mildewed―covered with mildew.

content: 2. (=生え出す)to spring up; to come up; to sprout

content.content: 毛が二三本生えた
A few hairs have sprung up.
種を蒔いたら生えた
The seeds have come up.
蒔かぬ種は生えぬ
“You must sow before you can reap.”
夏は黴が生える
In summer, bread grows mouldy―becomes covered with mould―shoes and clothes get mildewed―become covered with mildew.
この子は歯が生えるところだ
The child is cutting its teeth―teething.
歯がまだ生え揃わない
It has not cut all its teeth yet.
雛はまだ羽毛が生えぬ
The chicks are not yet fledged―unfledged―callow.
羽毛の生え立ての雛
a fledgling
羽が生える
to grow wings
本は羽根が生えて飛ぶように売れる
The book sells like wildfire.

content:
はおう〔覇王〕
〈名〉A potentate

content.content: 彼は実業界の覇王だ
He is the king of the business world.
英国は海上の覇王である
England is the mistress of the sea.

content:
ばおくれ〔場後れ〕
〈名〉Nervousness; stage-fright:(=する) to be nervous; to have stage-fright; to be stage-struck

content.content: 僕は試験場に出ると場後れして困る
I am nervous at examinations.
初舞台の時は場後れするものだ
When one appears on the stage for the first time, one will experience stage-fright.

はおと〔羽音〕
〈名〉The whir of wings

はおり〔羽織〕
〈名〉A Japanese coat

はおりごろつき〔羽織ゴロツキ〕
〈名〉A swell loafer

はおる〔羽織る〕
〈他動〉To throw on (a cloak, etc.)

content:
はか〔捗〕
〈名〉Progress

content.content: はかが行く
to make good progress
はかが行かぬ
to make little progress

content:
はか〔墓〕
〈名〉A grave; a tomb; a sepulchre; one's last home

content.content: 人が死ぬと死骸は墓に葬られる
When a man dies, his remains are consigned to the grave.
墓に詣る
to visit a grave―pay a visit to a grave
墓をあばく
to open a grave―dig a grave open
墓に氏無し
The grave knows no distinction of persons.

content:
ばか〔馬鹿〕
〈名〉
1. (人にだまされるばか者)a fool; an ass; a goose; a simpleton:(愚鈍なばか者) a dunce; a blockhead:(ばかな事) folly; foolishness; stupidity:(=な) foolish; silly; stupid; dull; dull-witted; weak-minded; imbecile

content.content: 貴様はばかだ
You're a fool.
そう言う貴様もばかだ
So are you―You are another.
このばかめ
You fool!
あのばかめ
The fool!
ばか呼ばわりする
to call one a fool―call one names
貴様は俺をばかだと思うか
Do you take me for a fool?
大ばかだ、からばかだ
He is a blooming fool―a desperate fool―an egregious ass―a holy imbecile―an idiot.
僕は何というばかだろう
Fool that I am!
彼はなかなかばかじゃない
He is no fool.
彼の言うことはばかじゃないがすることはばかだ
He talks like a man of sense, but his actions are those of a fool.
そんなことをするのはばかの骨頂だ
It is the height of folly to do such a thing.
ばかも程がある
You carry your folly too far.
もうばかを止せ
Enough of this folly!―No more of such follies!
君はあんな者を信用するとはどうしたばかだ
How foolish of you to trust such a man!
ばかと気違いはよけて通せ
“Make way for a fool and a madman!”
ばかと鋏は使いよう
Fools and scissors need nice handling.
ばかの一心恐るべし
Even a fool, bent on one thing, will do wonders.
ばかほど怖いものは無い
A fool does not know what he is doing.
ばかにかまうと日が暮れる
I will not waste words upon a fool―Words are wasted upon a fool.
貴様のようなばかには物言わぬ
I will not waste words upon you.
ばか骨折る
to be a fool for one's pains
ばかな子ほど可愛い
A dunce is all the dearer to his parents.
勉強ばかりさせて遊ばせないと子どもがばかになる
“All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy.”
どんなばかでも同じ手を二度は喰わぬ
“It is a silly fish that is caught twice with the same bait.”
ばかに付ける薬なし
“No medicine can cure folly.”
親ばか
“It is a wise father who knows his own child.”
ばかなことをする
to do a foolish thing―commit a folly
僕は商売を止めてばかなことをした
I committed a folly in giving up my business.
僕は(女にかかって)ばかのまねをした
I have played the fool.
四十のばかは本当のばか
“A fool at forty is a fool indeed.”
ばかなまねをするな
Don't make an ass of yourself!―Don't make a show of yourself!
彼はばかのありたけをし尽した
He has committed every conceivable folly―left no folly uncommitted―completed the sum of follies―run through the catalogue of follies―ranged over the gamut of folly.
僕はそんなばかなことはせぬ
I will not do such a foolish thing―(を通例)―I know better (than to do such a thing).
彼はあの年でばかなことをしたもんだ
He should know better at his age.
君の年でそんなばかなことをするものじゃない
You should know better at your age.
商売を止めるとはばかなことをしたもんだ
He should have known better than to give up his business.
彼はそんなばかなことをするはずが無い
He must know better.
あの苦労人がそんなばかなことをするはずが無い
He is too much of a man of the world not to know better.
彼は内の恥を外にさらすようなばかなことをする
He knows no better than to wash his dirty linen in public.
彼は生業を恥るようなばかだ
He knows no better than to quarrel with his bread and butter.
自分の家に火をつけるようなばかだ
He knows no better to set fire to his own house.
君がそんなばかなことをしようとは思わなかった
I did not think you would do such a foolish thing―(を通例)―I gave you credit for more sense.
ばかなことを言う
to say silly things―talk nonsense
彼はあまりばかなことを言うから皆抱腹絶倒する
He throws us into convulsions by saying silly things.
ばかを言うな
Don't take nonsense!―Don't talk rot!
ばか言え、ばかぬかせ
Nonsence!―Stuff!―Stuff and nonsense!
ばかをみる
to commit a folly―be a fool for one's pains
こんな仕事を引受けてばかを見たのは僕さ
I committed a folly in undertaking such a work―I was a fool for my pains.
人にだまされて無駄足を運んでばかをみた
I went on a fool's errand.
人をばかにする
to despise―defy―snub―sit upon―trifle with―play with―laugh at―a man
田舎だとてそうばかにしたものじゃない
The country is not to be despised.
人をばかにしあがって
You are trifling with me.
人をばかにするない
Don't trifle with me!
人をばかにすると承知せんぞ
He shall know that I am to be trifled with.
彼は人をばかにしきっている
He despises us―He defies us―He is laughing at us.
あんな者共にばかにされて黙っている奴があるか
How can you suffer yourself to be snubbed―to be sat upon―by such fellows?
お前は親をばかにしている(親の威光を眼中におかぬ)
You defy paternal authority―set paternal authority at defiance.
人を馬鹿にしたような風をして僕の顔を見た
He looked in my face with a contemptuous air.
(こんな物を本物だなんて)ずいぶん人をばかにした話だ、あまりといえば人をばかにしている
It is an insult to one's understanding―an affront to one's intelligence.
ばかにしてら
Nonsense!―Humbug!

content:
6. 
〈以下特例〉

content.content: 時計がばかになる
A clock gets out of order.
鼻を使わないとばかになる
Your nose, if not used, gets out of practice.
感覚がばかになる
Sensation dulls―gets dull―gets dulled.
あまり酒を飲むと頭がばかになる
Wine makes the head dull―Wine dulls the head.
長くすわっていると足がばかになる
Your legs gets benumbed―gets asleep―after long sitting.
人に長たる者はばかになっている必要がある
A ruler of men must see everything and say nothing.
この商売はなかなかばかにならぬ
The business is not bad―not to be despised―not to be sneezed at.
子どもだといってばかにならぬものだ
Children will speak the truth.
ばかのずうたい
“Ill weeds grow apace.”

content.content: 事務がはかどる
Business makes good progress.
仕事がはかどりますか
Does your work make good progress?―How are you getting along with your work?
はかどります
It is making good progress―I am getting along very well with it.
工事がはかどっている
The works are well forward.
工事がいっこうはかどらぬ
The works make little progress―progress at a snail's pace.
今日は道がはかどった
We have done a good journey today.

content:
はかない〔果敢ない〕
〈形〉Mutable (world); unstable (existence); fleeting (life); transient (prosperity); transitory (glory); passing (dream); ephemeral (grandeur); fugitive (happiness); fugacious (splendour); evanescent (blossom); vain (things of this life); hopeless (love); frail (hope); fragile (good); sudden (death); poor (orphan, etc.)

content.content: 世ははかなきもの
How mutable is the world!
人生ははかなきもの
Life is fleeting―Life is transitory―Life is evanescent―Life is but a span.
この世の栄華ははかなきもの
How vain is the splendour of this world!
美貌ははかなきもの
Beauty is a fragile good.
彼ははかなき最後をとげた
He met with a sudden death.
哀れこの子は身寄り頼りも無いはかない身です
He is a poor orphan without kith or kin.
今にも別れるはかない身じゃないか
Alas! we must part very soon.
はかなくなる
to die
彼は哀れはかなくなりました
Alas! he is no more.
でははかなくなったか
He is gone, then.

content:
はかなさ〔果敢なさ〕
〈名〉Mutability (of the world); instability (of human affairs); vanity (of human splendour); transiency (of prosperity, etc.)

content.content: 世のはかなさを思う
to muse on the mutability of human affairs―muse on the vanity of human things

content.content: 世をはかなむ
to be sick of life―be weary of the world

a heartsick man―a pessimist

content.content: 値段がばかに高い
It is absurdly dear―awfully dear―confoundedly dear―too dear.
ばかに安い
It is absurdly cheap―dog-cheap―dirt-cheap.
今日はばかに暑い
It is awfully hot―devilishly hot―today.
そういう人はばかに多い
Such men are to be found by the cartload.

はかば〔墓場〕

こんなばかばかしい事は無い
Nothing can be more absurd―Nothing can exceed the absurdity.
彼はばかばかしいほど几帳面だ
He is punctilious to an absurd extent―to the extent of absurdity.

content:

どうぞしかるべくはからってくれ給え

それだけのことか、よいようにはからっておこう

この儀如何にはからいましょうか

私一存でははからいかねます

万事不都合の無いようにはからってくれ

双方に不平の無いように公平にはからいます

content:
ばかり〔計り〕
〈副〉
1. (=ほとんど)about

content.content: 五十ばかり
about fifty―somewhere about fifty―in the neighbourhood of fifty―in the vicinity of fifty―in the region of fifty―some fifty
一マイルばかり行ったころ人に逢った
I had gone about a mile―a matter of a mile―when I met a man.

content: 2. (=だけ)only; but

content.content: 彼は金ばかり欲しがる
He hankers after money only.
彼ができるのはこればかりだ
He can do only this―this only.
夢に見たばかり
I only dreamed it.
彼は怠けるばかりだ
He is only idle.
彼は読み書きができるばかりだ
He can only read and write.
彼には昨日逢ったばかりだ
I met his only yesterday―but yesterday―It was only yesterday―but yesterday―that I met him.
彼は近ごろ来たばかりだ
He came only lately―but lately―It was only lately―but lately―that he came.
宵にちらりと見たばかりだ

心ばかりのご馳走です
It is an entertainment only meant to show my good-will.
あの人は自分の都合の好いことばかり言っている
He only consults his own convenience.
(顔は真黒に日に焼けて)目ばかり光っている
His eyes only are bright.
(何でも上げますから)命ばかりはお助けを
Only spare my life!
彼は学者とは名ばかりだ
He is a scholar in name only.
あるものは借金ばかり
He has debts only.

content: 3. (=だけ)merely; solely; barely

content.content: 彼は怠けるばかりだ
He is merely idle.
彼は学者とは名ばかりだ
He is a scholar solely in name.
読み書きができるばかりだ
He can merely read and write.
皆彼の足音を聞いたばかりでふるえあがっている
They tremble at the mere sound of his footsteps.
彼の名を聞いたばかりで皆驚くだろう
They will be surprised at the mere mention of his name.
(金を残すどころか)借金をせぬばかり
I can barely keep out of debt.
(泳ぐのはさておいて)浮いていたばかりさ
I barely kept myself above water.
ただ約束を履行したというばかり
He barely fulfilled his promise.
彼はただ及第したというばかり
He barely passed his examination.
想像したばかりでゾッとする
I shudder at bare idea.
この商売はかながな暮らして行くというばかりです
I can make a bare living by my trade.

content: 4. (=だけ)the very

content.content: 顔を見たばかりで気がすむ
The very sight of her face satisfies me―The mere sight of her face satisfies me.
そんなことを考えたばかりで死んでしまいそうだ
The very thought would kill me―The mere thought would kill me.
彼の名を聞いたばかりで驚くだろう
His very name would astonish them.
君がすわっているばかりでたくさんだ
Your very presence will do―Your mere presence will do.
(人が金を出すのを見たらさすがのちけも)恥かしいばかりで多少出すだろう
He will give something from very shame.

content: 5. (=のみ)the only

content.content: あるものはこればかり
This is the only thing there is.
知っているのはそればかり
That is the only thing that I know.
物を言うのは人間ばかり
Man is the only creature that can speak.
皇統連綿は日本ばかり
Japan is the only country that boasts an unbroken line of sovereigns.
僕の友人としては君ばかりだ
You are the only friend I have―You are my only friend.
そう言って下さるのは貴方ばかり
You are the only man who says so to me.
彼は金ばかり欲しがる
Money is the only thing that he wants.
これができるのはあの人ばかりだ
He is the only man who can do this.
町内で知らぬは亭主ばかりなり
“The good man is the only one who does not know what is amiss at home.”

content: 6. (=のみ)alone

content.content: 物を言うのは人間ばかり
Man alone has the gift of speech.
皇統連綿は日本ばかり
Japan alone boasts an unbroken line of sovereigns.
顔を見たばかりじゃ気がすまない
The sight alone does not satisfy me.
僕ばかり悪いのではない
I am not alone to blame.

content: 7. (=のみ)all; always

content.content: あるものはとこればかり
These are all the things there are.
ある金はこればかり
This is all the money there is.
知っているのはそればかり
That is all I know.
そればかりではない
That is not all.
正直な人ばかりでは無い
All men are not honest.
あの人は口ばかりで実行が無い
He is all talk and no deed.
勉強ばかりさせて遊ばせないと子どもがばかになる
“All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy.”
骨と皮ばかり
He is all skin and bones―reduced to a skeleton.
彼はキョロキョロ眺めてばかりいる
He is all eyes.
彼女はニコニコ笑ってばかりいる
She is all smiles.
彼は内に引込んでばかりいる
He always cowers at home.
遊んでばかりいる
He is always playing―playing all the time.
あの人は自分勝っての好い事ばかり言っている
He always consults his own convenience.
今日は腹の立つことばかりある日だ
Everything goes wrong with me today.

content: 8. (=のみ)nothing but; none but

content.content: あるものは借金ばかり
He has nothing but debts.
物を言うのは人間ばかり
No creature can speak but man.
皇統連綿は日本ばかり
No country boasts an unbroken line of sovereigns but Japan.
僕の友人としては君ばかり
I have no friend but you.
四方は山ばかり
There are nothing but mountains on every side.
彼は学者とは名ばかり
He is a scholar in nothing but the name.

content: 9. (=何々ばかりしている)to do nothing but...

content.content: 彼女は泣いてばかりいる
She does nothing but cry.
彼は朝から晩まで酒ばかり飲んでいる
He does nothing but drink from morning till night.
彼らは不平ばかり鳴らしている
They do nothing but complain.
彼は女ばかり口説いている
He does nothing but make love to the girls.
彼女は小説ばかり読んでいる
She does nothing but read novels.
この子は遊んでばかりいる
The boy does nothing but play.

content: 10. (=こればかりは、とばかりは)anything but

content.content: (命でも)何でも上げますがこの金ばかりは上げられぬ
I will give you anything but this money.
彼は何でもするが勉強ばかりはせぬ
He will do anything but work―Work is the last thing he will do.
このことばかりはご免を蒙ります
I will do anything but this.
貴方のためなら何でもするがそればかりは(まっぴら)
I will do anything for your sake but that.
その儀ばかりは
I will do anything but that.
このことばかりは承諾しかねます
I would consent to anything but that―That is the last thing I would consent to.
彼はどう評しても豪傑とばかりは言えぬ
He is anything but a hero―Whatever else he may be, he is not a hero―Whatever else you may say of him, you can not say that he is a hero.
彼はどうほめても謙遜家とばかりは言えぬ
He is anything but modest―Whatever else you may call him, you can not call him modest―No flatterer would describe him as modest―Flattery itself would not count modesty among his virtues.

content: 11. (=何々と言わぬばかり)all but

content.content: 王と言わぬばかり
Cromwell was all but a king―a king in all but the name.
彼は(生きているとは名ばかりで)死んだと言わぬばかり
He is all but dead―as good as dead―virtually dead―practically dead―He is, to all intents and purposes, a dead man.
建物は倒れないばかりだ
The buildings are all but falling.

content: 12. (=何々ばかりで)except for

content.content: 土人はふんどし一本締めているばかりで素裸
The native is naked, except for a loin-cloth.
番人がいるばかりで家は空
The house is deserted, except for the keeper.
市街は当番の巡査が立っているばかりで火の消えたよう
The streets are deserted, except for the policemen on duty.
彼は怠けるばかりで別に非難すべき点が無い
He is blameless, except for his idleness.

content: 13. (=何々するばかり)to go on (doing something)

content.content: 物価は上がるばかりだ
The prices go on rising―The prices are ever on the rise.
彼の財産は殖えるばかりだ
His wealth goes on increasing―His wealth is ever on the increase.
借金が殖えるばかりだ
The debts go on increasing―The debts are ever on the increase.
金はドンドン儲かるばかり
He goes on coining money.

content: 〈以下特例〉

content.content: (酒を飲まないから)金が残るばかりだ
He can not help growing rich.

content: 14. (=今何々したばかり)(to have) just, only just, but just (done something)

content.content: 彼は英語を始めたばかりだ
He has just begun English.
僕は今来たばたりだ
I have only just come.
彼は今着いたばかりだ
He has but just arrived.
彼と今別れて来たばかりだ
I have only just parted from him.
彼は長患いをして直ったばかりだ
He has only just recovered from a long illness.
練習は始まったばかり
School has just begun.
鐘が鳴ったばかりだ
The bell has just rung.
汽車は今たったばかりだ
The train has only just started.
買ったばかりの時計を取られた
I lost a watch I had just bought.

content: 15. (=何々したばかりの)just from, fresh from (some place)

content.content: 米国から来たばかりの米国人だ
He is an American just from America―straight from America.
洋行して帰ったばかりの人に逢った
I have met a man just returned from abroad.
彼は学校を出たばかりのお嬢さんを細君に貰った
He has married a miss fresh from school.
田舎から来たばかりの女中だ
She is a maid-servant fresh from the country.
蒸したばかりの焼芋
baked potatoes hot from the oven
刷ったばかりの新聞
papers wet from the press―damp from the press

content: 16. (=何々するばかりに)(to be) ready for (something)

content.content: 品物は売るばかりに、市へ出すばかりにできている
The goods are ready for sale―ready for the market.
本は印刷するばかりに出来ている
The book is ready for the press.
飯は焚くばかりに用意してある
The rice is ready for boiling.
魚は煮るばかりに、焼くばかりにこしらえてある
The fish is ready for the pot―ready for the fire.

content: 17. (=何々せんばかり)(to be) ready (to do something); (to be) about (to do something); (to be) on the point of (doing something)

content.content: 船は沈まんばかりであった
The ship was ready to sink.
女は泣き出さんばかりであった
She was ready to cry.
汽車は今たったばかりだ
The train is ready to start―about to start―on the point of starting.
城が陥落せんばかりのところへ援兵が来た
The castle was about to fall―on the point of falling―when the reinforcements arrived.

content: 〈以下特例〉

content.content: 死なんばかりに驚いた
I was frightened to death.

content: 18. (=ただ何々せぬというばかり)(It is) all one can do, as much as one can do (to do something)

content.content: (金を残すどころか)ただ借金せぬというばかり
It is all I can do―as much as I can do―to keep out of debt.
(泳ぐのはさておいて)ただ浮いていたというばかり
It was all I could do to keep myself afloat―as much as I could do to keep myself above water.
彼は生きているというばかりだ
It is all he can do―as much as he can do―to keep alive.

content: 19. (=ばかりでなく)not only, not merely (... but also...)

content.content: 彼は学問ができるばかりでなく教え方も上手だ
He is not only a good scholar, but also a good teacher―He is a good teacher as well as a good scholar.
彼は英語ばかりでなく仏語独語もできる
He knows not only English, but French and German―He knows French and German as well as English.
英語を話すばかりでなく英文をも書く
He not merely speaks English, but also writes it―He writes as well as speaks English.

content:
20. 
〈以上の共通点〉

content.content: 夢に見たばかり
I only dreamed it―merely dreamed it.
彼は怠るばかりだ
He is only idle―merely idle.
彼は学者とは名ばかり
He is a scholar only in name―solely in name―in nothing but the name.
この子は遊んでばかりいる
The boy is always playing―The boy does nothing but play.
顔をみたばかりで気がすむ
The sight of her face―The mere sight of her face―The very sight of her face―would satisfy me.
彼の名を聞いたばかりで驚くだろう
They would be astonished at the mere mention of his name―His very name would astonish them.
皇統連綿は日本ばかり
Japan alone boasts an unbroken line of sovereigns―Japan is the only country that boasts an unbroken line of sovereigns―No country boasts an unbroken line of sovereigns but Japan.
物を言うのは人間ばかり
Man alone can speak―Man is the only creature that can speak―No creature can speak but man.
知っているのはそればかり
That is all I know―That is the only thing I know.
あの人は金ばかり欲しがる
He hankers after money only―Money is the only thing he wants.
借金をせぬと言うばかり
I can barely keep out of debt―It is all I can do to keep, out of debt.
あれよあれよと騒ぐばかり
They could only cry out in alarm―All they could do was to cry out in alarm.

content:
21. 
〈以下特例〉

content.content: ひと目見たばかりですっかり様子がわかった
I understood the whole story at a glance.
ここばかりは日は照らぬ
The sun shines everywhere―I have all the world before me.
彼は自分ばかり偉い気になっている
He fancies himself an important person.
気ばかりはやって足は進まぬ
“The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak.”
江戸ッ子は口先ばかり強い
The Edokko is a barking dog.
(ああは言うものの)あれは口ばかりだ
It is empty talk.
あの人は好いことばかり続く
He has a run of luck.
あの女は不幸せばかり続く
She has met with a series of misfortunes―had a chapter of accidents.
彼は死んだものとばかり思っておった
I supposed he was dead.
二人は夫婦仲のよいこととばかり思っておった
I thought they were happy together.
彼は満足していることとばかり思っていた
I never doubted that he was contented.
彼は僕を殴らんばかりの権幕であった
He threatened to strike me.
彼は不在とばかりで誰にも会わぬ
He is never at home to any one.
彼は主義だとばかりで決して酒を飲まぬ
He parades his principle and never drinks.
知らぬとばかりでどうしても言わぬ
He persists in denying his knowledge.
大きなお世話といわぬばかりの顔をした
She looked as much as to say, “Mind your own business!”
これは日本ばかりだ、日本ばかりでない
This is limited to Japan―not limited to Japan.

content: 〈形〉(=こればかりの、そればかりの、あればかりの)so little; so scanty; so trifling; so paltry

content.content: こればかりの金で何ができるものか
What can be done with such a paltry sum?
そればかりの給料でどうして暮らして行けるか
How do you manage to live on such scanty pay?
こればかりの物を貰って返礼をするには及ぶまい
I need not give anything in return for such a trifling present.

はかりうり〔量り売り〕
〈名〉Sale by measure:(=する) to sell by measure; to sell by the bushel; to sell by the quart

content:
はかりがたい〔測り難い〕
〈形〉Unfathomable (sea); mysterious (fate); inscrutable (Providence); uncertain (result, etc.)

content.content: 運命ははかり難し
Fate is mysterious―a mystery to man―a sealed book to us.
天道ははかり難し
“Inscrutable are the ways of Heaven.”
はかり難きは人の栄枯である
Mysterious are the vicissitudes of life.
彼の心中ははかり難い
His mind is unfathomable―He is deep.
結果ははかり難い
The result is uncertain.
何事が起こるかはかり難い
There is no saying what may happen.

content:
はかりごと〔謀、計〕
〈名〉A stratagem (of war); a scheme (for a world empire); a design (of conquest); a plan (of escape); a plot (for assassination); an artifice, a device, a trick, a ruse (to lure the enemy); a trap; a snare; (a man fertile in) resources

content.content: 計{はかりごと}をめぐらす
to revolve a scheme―contrive a scheme―devise a stratagem―concoct a plot―form a design―lay a plan
計が図に当たった
The stratagem took.
計がはずれた
The stratagem failed.
計に富む
He is full of resource―fertile in resources―a man of resources.
計をもって城を取る
to take a castle by stratagem
計をもって敵を釣り出す
to lure the enemy by artifice
あれは我々に油断をさせる計だ
That is a ruse to throw us off our guard.
計に陥る
to fall into a snare―walk into a trap
敵を計に陥れる
to ensnare the enemy―entrap the enemy
計に乗ぜられる
to be caught in a trap
計の裏をかく
to baffle one's design―baulk one's design―defeat one's design―foil one's design―frustrate one's design
計が敗れる
to be baffled in one's design―be baulked in one's design―be defeated in one's design―be foiled in one's design―be frustrated in one's design
計が尽きた
I am at the end of my resources―at my wits' end―driven to my last shifts.
謀は密なるを尚{たっと}ぶ
“Secrecy is the soul of strategy.”
一年の計は元旦にあり
The New Year's Day is the key of the year―(に相当するは)―“The first hour of the morning is the key of the day.”

はかりざお〔秤竿〕
〈名〉The beam (of a balance)

はかりざら〔秤皿〕
〈名〉The scales (of a balance)

はかりやすい〔謀り易い〕
〈形〉(A man) easy to deal with

content:
はかる〔計る、度る、量る、測る〕
〈名〉To measure (rice―the height of a mountain); to weigh (a fish); to calculate, compute, estimate (the number or quantity); to gauge (the rainfall); to survey (land); to sound, plumb (the sea); to fathom (one's mind); to judge of (a man)

content.content: 山の高さを測る
to measure the height of a mountain
山の高さを測ってみると三千尺ある
The mountain measures 3000 feet in height.
身長を測る
to measure one's height
海の深さを測る
to sound the sea―take sounding―heave the laed
時は時間で計る
Time is measured by the hour.
体温を測る
to take one's temperature
桝で量る
to measure (rice, etc.)
あんな人間は桝で量るくらいある
Such men are to be found by the cartload.
風力を量る
to gauge the wind
雨量を量る
to gauge the rainfall
目分量で計る
to measure by the eye―estimate by the eye―judge by the eye
距離を足で測る
to pace the distance
長さを手の指で測る
to span the length
人の貫目を量る
to take one's measure
己をもって人をはかるな
Do not judge of others by yourself―measure another's feet by your own last.
程合を計る
to use moderation
暴風雨襲来するやもはかられず
A storm may visit us.→『はかりがたい〔測り難い〕』

content:

〈他動〉To consult (one's convenience); to provide for (one's safety); to look to (one's interests); to bring about (a reconciliation); to labour for (one's good); to promote (sociability); to study (one's happiness, welfare, etc.)

頭禿げても浮気が止まぬ

付け焼刃ははげやすい
Borrowed plumes will come off―False dye will not wash―Plated work will not stand wear and tear.
嘘は後からはげる

化けの皮がはげる
to show one's true colours―show the cloven hoof―betray the cloven foot―betray oneself

content:

content.content: 開校の運びになっている
Things have progressed far enough to open the school―Everything is ready for opening the school.
まだ開校の運びに至らず
Things have not yet progressed far enough to open the school―We are not yet ready to open the school.
線路はまだ開通の運びに至らず

運びをつける
to arrange the matter―settle the matter―bring the matter about―bring the matter to a successful issue―put the matter through―carry the matter through
どうかこうか運びをつけた
We have managed to put it through―carry it through―bring the matter to a successful issue.
なるべく早く運びをつけてもらいたい

ここへ運べ

content.content: 両軍は河を挟んで相対した

前後より敵を挟んで討った
We attached the enemy―in front and rear―We had the enemy between two fires.

content.content: 日本人と支那人は箸で食う
The Japanese and Chinese eat with chopsticks.

箸を下す、箸を取る、箸をつける
to touch food―eat
料理があまりまずそうだから箸をつけなかった
I did not touch the dish, it looked so unsavoury.
箸の上げ下ろしにも小言を言う
She finds faults with everything I do.

〈名〉→『

content:
はじ〔恥〕
〈名〉
1. Shame; disgrace; dishonour; reproach; humiliation; ignominy; contumely; obloquy:(侮辱の意味なら)an insult

content.content: 恥は死ぬに劣る
“Shame is worse than death.”
あんな息子を持ったのは親の恥だ
Such a son is a disgrace to his parents.
自国語を知らないのは恥だ
It is a disgrace not to know one's own language.
本懐を遂げないのは男の恥だ
It concerns a man's honour to fail in attaining his object.
思いを遂げないのは女の恥だ
It is a point of honour with a woman to succeed in love.
父無し子は母の一生の恥だ
A bastard is a standing reproach to his mother.
働いて飯を食うのは恥でない
It is honourable to work for one's bread.
死すべき時に死せざれば死に勝る恥あり
A man must sometimes die or live in dishonour―choose between death and dishonour.
問うは一時の恥問わぬは一生の恥
Be not ashamed to learn, and you escape a lifelong shame.
長生きすれば恥多し
“To live long is to outlive much.”
据膳食わぬは男の恥
One must not refuse a lady's advances.
何を恥とする
to consider anything beneath one's dignity―hold anything infra dig
僕は人に恩恵を乞うことを恥とする
I consider it beneath my dignity to ask a favour―I disdain to ask a favour.
武士は営利的の事業を恥とした
The samurai considered it beneath him to engage in lucrative business.
恥を知る
to have a sense of honour―to be sensible to shame―alive to the feeling of honour
日本人は恥を知る
The Japanese have a delicate sense of honour―The Japanese are keenly alive to the feeling of honour.
少しは恥を知れ
You should have some sense of honour―You have no sense of honour.
恥を知る人
a man of honour
彼は恥を知らぬ、恥を恥とも思わぬ
He has no sense of honour―He is shameless―insensible to shame―dead to shame―lost to virtue.
恥知らずだ
He is a shameless fellow―a brazen faced fellow.
恥を掻く
to suffer disgrace―disgrace oneself―bring disgrace on oneself―cover oneself with shame―be covered with shame―be clothed wit disgrace―be put to shame―be put to the blush
語学で男が女子の前で恥をかくことがある
In English, a school-girl might put you to shame―put you to the blush.
人前で恥をかく
to be put to shame in company―look foolish in company―expose one's ignorance in public
知るべきことを知らないと人中で恥をかく
If you are ignorant of what you ought to know, you will look foolish in company.
人中で恥をかいてはならないから尋ねることもできない
I can't be asking questions, for it would never do to expose my ignorance in public.
人に恥をかかせる
(侮辱するの意味なら)to insult one―(赤面さすの意味なら)―put one to shame―put one to the blush
人中で恥をかかせられた
I was insulted in public.
人に不得意なことをさせて恥をかかせる
to play a man off
僕に恥をかかしてくれるな
You must keep me in countenance.
君に恥をかかせるようなことはせぬ
I will keep you in countenance.
死ぬか恥をかくか二つの一つを選ぶ
to choose between death and dishonour
恥を掻くならむしろ死ぬ
I would rather die than live in dishonour I should prefer death to dishonour―I would choose death before dishonour.
死すとも恥かくな
Death before dishonour!
人は死にようによっては死に恥をかく
One may die an ignominious death.
彼はどんな恥をかいても平気だ
Nothing can abash him.
この恥かきめ
Fie! For shame!
旅の恥はかき捨て
“Once over the borders, one may do anything.”
恥をさらす
to make oneself ridiculous―make an ass of oneself―make a show of oneself―make an exhibition oneself
人中で恥をさらすな
Don't make an ass of yourself!
なんという恥さらしだ
What an ass!
生き恥をさらす
to outlive one's fame―drag out a miserable existence
醜業婦は世に恥をさらす
A woman of the town lives a life of shame.
内の恥を外にさらす(暗闇の恥を明るみに出す)
to wash one's dirty linen in public
恥をそそぐ
to wipe out a disgrace―wipe away a reproach―clear one's reputation―vindicate one's honour―vindicate one's character
彼は最後の成功で恥をそそいだ
His final success has wiped away his reproach―taken away his reproach.
恥を忍ぶ
to endure obloquy―put up with contumelies―drug one's sense of shame―eat dirt―eat crow―eat humble-pie―(一回の恥なら)―swallow an insult――pocket an insult―digest an insult―stomach an insult
こんな恥はとても忍べぬ
I can't stomach such an insult.
彼は恥を忍んで敵の世話になった
He ate humble-pie, and received assistance at his enemy's hands.
恥を忍んで本懐を遂ぐるのが真性の勇気
He who can put up with wrongs and contumelies in order to attain his object, has genuine courage.
犬侍と言われても恥を忍んで主人の仇を討ったのは偉い
Who can but admire the man who suffered himself to be called a dog of a knight, that he might avenge his master's death?
恥を捨てる
to cast shame behind one―live in open shame
恥の上塗りをする
to make oneself doubly ridiculous
一度の失敗で止せば好いのに恥の上塗りをしてしまった
Not content with a single failure, he must go and make another mess of it.

content:
はじいる〔恥入る〕
〈自動〉To be ashamed

content.content: まことに恥入る次第です
I am really ashamed of myself―overwhelmed with shame.

content:
はしか〔麻疹〕
〈名〉The measles

content.content: はしかにかかる
to catch the measles
子どもがはしかにかかっている
The child has the measles.
君ははしかがすんだか
Have you had the measles?

はしがき〔端書〕
〈名〉A preface; a prefatory note

content:
はじかき〔恥掻き〕
〈名〉
1. (=恥をかくこと)making oneself ridiculous

content.content: (断れたら)好い恥かきだ
What a ridiculous figure I should cut if I should be refused!

content: 2. (=笑われて恥をかく人)an ass

content.content: この恥かきめ
What an ass!―Fie! For shame!

はじき〔弾き〕
〈名〉(=弾き金)A spring

content:
はじく〔弾く〕
〈他動〉
1. (=はねとばす)to send flying with a sudden impulse

content.content: 爪で弾く
to flip a coin―fillip dust
指を弾く
to snap one's fingers
(水鉄砲で)水を弾く
to squirt water―flirt water

content: 2. (=うけつけぬ)to reject; to repel

content.content: 油は水を弾く
Oil repels water.
合羽は水を弾く
A rain-coat sheds water.
鳥の毛は水を弾く
Water slides off a duck's back.
フランネルは汗を弾く
Flannel does not get moist with sweat.
女の袖を引いて弾かれた
He made love to her, and got rejected―got a rebuff.

content: 3. (=省く)to exclude

content.content: 試験で弾かれた
I got plucked.

content:
はしくれ〔端くれ〕
〈名〉The fag-end

content.content: 華族のはしくれ
the fog-end of nobility
これでも役人のはしくれです
I hold the fag-end of government office.

content:
はしけ〔艀舟〕
〈名〉A sampan; a lighter

content.content: はしけ賃
sampan fare

はじけまめ〔弾け豆〕
〈名〉Parched peas

content:
はじける〔弾ける〕
〈自動〉To burst open; to split open

content.content: 栗の毬が弾ける
A chestnut-burr bursts open.
桶のたがが弾ける
A hoop springs off a tub.

content:
はしご〔梯子〕
〈名〉A ladder

content.content: 屋根に梯子をかける
to set a ladder against the roof
屋根に梯子がかかっている
A ladder stands against the roof.
梯子を登る
to climb a ladder
梯子を下る
to go down the ladder―descend the ladder
梯子の段
a round―a rung
あの人の酒は梯子だ
He must visit two or three tea-houses before going home.

content:
はしごだん〔梯子段〕
〈名〉A staircase; (a flight of) stairs

content.content: 梯子段を上り下りする
to go up and down the stairs
梯子段から落ちる
to fall down the stairs
梯子段ですれ違った
I passed him on the stairs.
梯子段の下に立っていた
He was standing at the bottom of the stairs.
梯子段の上に立っていた
He was standing at the top of the stairs.
梯子の段の上の溜りで客を迎える
I shall receive the guests at the landing.

content:
はしごのぼり〔梯子登り〕
〈名〉Climbing a ladder; climbing over hand

content.content: 物価は梯子登りに登る
The prices rise hand over hand―rise by leaps and bounds.

はしごのり〔梯子乗り〕
〈名〉Performance on a ladder

content:
はじさらし〔恥曝し〕
〈名〉
1. (=恥をさらすこと)making oneself ridiculous

content.content: 断られたらそれこそ好い恥さらしだ
What a ridiculous figure I should cut if I should be refused!

content: 2. (=恥をさらす人)an ass

content.content: この恥さらしめ
What an ass!―Fie! For shame!

content:
はじしめる〔恥しめる〕
〈他動〉→『

content.content: はずかしめ〔辱め〕

はじしらず〔恥知らず〕
〈形〉Shameless; insensible to shame; dead to shame; lost to virtue:(名詞に用いれば)a shameless fellow; a brazen-faced fellow

content:
はした〔端下〕
〈名〉A fraction:(=の) fraction; odd

content.content: 十を三で割るとはしたが出る
10 divided by 3 leaves a fraction.
はしたを切捨てる
to omit fractions
はしたの五十銭だけおまけ申します
I will take off the odd 50 sen.

content:
はしたがね〔端下金〕
〈名〉A paltry sum; a pittance

content.content: そんなはした金には目をくれない
I am not tempted by such a paltry sum.
そんなはした金のために働くのはいやだ
I will not work for such a pittance.

はしたない
〈形〉
1. (=どちらにもつかぬ)neither the one nor the other
2. (=きまり悪し)(to be) embarrassed
3. (=賤しい)low; mean; base

はしため〔はした女〕
〈名〉A maid-servant; a waiting woman

はしたもの〔端下物〕
〈名〉Odds and ends

content:
はしぢか〔端近〕
〈名〉The outer end of a room

content.content: そこは端近、いざまずこれへ
Pray, walk in!

content:
はしっこい
〈形〉Quick; sharp; smart; shrewd

content.content: はしっこく立ちまわる
to be quick―look sharp―go shrewdly to work

はしづめ〔橋詰め〕
〈名〉The approach to a bridge

content:
ばじとうふう〔馬耳東風〕
〈熟語〉Perfect indifference

content.content: あの男には何を言っても馬耳東風だ
Your words will slide off him like water off a duck's back―Your words will fall on deaf ears.

はしなく〔端無く〕
〈形〉By chance; by accident

content:
はしばみ〔榛〕
〈名〉The hazel

content.content: 榛の実
a hazel-nut

はしぶとがらす〔嘴太烏〕
〈名〉The raven

はしぼそがらす〔嘴細烏〕
〈名〉The crow

content:
はじまり〔始まり〕
〈名〉The beginning (of intercourse); the commencement (of a performance); the opening (of a meeting); the outbreak (of war)

content.content: 兄弟は他人の始まり
Brothers are incipient strangers―The world begins with brothers.

content:
はじまる〔始まる〕
〈自動〉
1. To begin; to commence

content.content: 授業は何時に始まるか
What time does school begin?
授業は八時に始まる
School begins at 8.
授業はもう始まったか
Has school begun yet?
授業はもう始まった
School has begun (already).
(驚いて)もう授業が始まったのか
Has school begun already?
今始まったばかりだ
It has (only) just begun.
新学期はいつ始まるか
When does the new term commence?
四月一日に始まる
It commences on the first of April.
戦いがいよいよ始まった
The battle has begun in earnest.
戦いが始まっている(進行中)
A battle is going on―in progress.
あそこに何が始まっているか
What is going on―going forward―over there?
舞踏が始まっている
Dancing is going on―going forward.
何から始まる
to begin with something
日本外史は平氏から始まって徳川時代で終る
The Nihon Gaishi begins with the Tairas, and ends with the Tokugawas.
千里の行も一歩より始まる
“He who would climb the ladder must begin at the bottom.”
いつから始まる
to date from some period［注意］“To begin from”と言うべからず。
岩崎家の繁栄は台湾戦争から始まった
The prosperity of the Iwasakis dates from the Formosan expedition.
彼との交際は学校時代から始まっている
Our intercourse dates from our school-days―began in our school-days.
入学試験は三日から始まる
The entrance examination begins on the 3rd.
誰から始まる
to originate with some one
いったいこの企ては誰から始まったことか(誰が発起人か)
With whom did the scheme originate?―Who is the originator of the scheme?
知事から始まったことだ
It originated with the Governor.

content:
5. 
〈以下特例〉

content.content: 戦争が始まる
War breaks out.
戦争に始まられて計画を中止した
We had the war break out, and abandoned the project.
猟期はいつ始まるか
When does the shooting season open?
入梅はいつ始まるか
When does the rainy season set in?
土用は明日始まる
The dog-days set in tomorrow.
また始まったね
You are at it again.
悪いことは酒から始まる
Drinking leads to other vices.
いまさらそんなことを言っても始まらない
It is no use talking now―Talking will not mend matters.
泣いたって始まらない
It is no use crying―Crying will not mend matters.
壊した茶碗を接いでみても始まらない
“It is no use crying over spilt milk.”

content:
はじめ〔始め、初め〕
〈名〉
1. The beginning (of the month); the commencement (of the term); the outset (of one's studies); the outbreak (of the war); the start (of one's career); the dawn (of reason); the origin (of things); the opening (of a season); the inception (of a movement); the initiation (of a reform); the inauguration (of a policy); the early part (of a century, etc.)

content.content: 始めるが大事
The beginning is important―“Well begun is half done.”
始め好ければ半ばの成功
A good beginning is half the battle―A good outset is half the journey―“Well begun is half done.”
逢うは別れの始め(ともいうべし)
Meeting is, in a sense, the beginning of parting.
生は死の始め(ともいうべし)
Birth is, in a manner, the beginning of death.
人生字を知るは憂の始め
Knowledge is the beginning of sorrow―Sorrow begins with knowledge.
明治の初めであった
It was the early years of Meiji.

content: 2. (=は) at first; at the start; at the outset; in the beginning

content.content: 始めは骨が折れるがじきに慣れる
You find hard work at first, but you soon get used to it.
始めはそう思った
At first, I thought so.
始めうまく行かなかった
It did not go well at the start.
あの学校は始めは微々たるものであった
In the beginning, the school was a petty affair.
始めは処女の如く終りは脱兎の如し
Be deliberate in council and prompt in action.

content: 3. (=に) at the beginning; at the start; at the outset

content.content: 始めに不規則動詞を暗記してしまう
Learn the irregular verbs at the outset―at the very outset.
彼は今月の始めに入学した
He entered at the beginning of the month.
僕は九月の始めに帰る
I shall be back at the beginning of September.
戦争の始めにはドイツが勝った
Germany was victorious at the outbreak of the war.

content: 4. (=の) first; original; initial

content.content: 初めの先生は米国人でした
My first teacher was an American.
初めの考えは工学者になるつもりでした
My first intention―My original intention―was to become an engineer.
姓名の初めの文字
the initial letters of my name―my initials
初めの勢どこへやら
His initial ardour has evaporated.
一日中の始めの時間
the early hours of the day

content: 5. (=から) from the beginning; from the first; from the outset

content.content: 始めから話をしよう
I will tell the story from the beginning.
始めから始めよう
I will begin at the beginning.
彼は始めからこの事業に着眼した
He had an eye to the enterprise from the first.
始めからうまくはできぬ
You can not do it well from the outset.
彼は始めから勝っておって
He gained on the others from the start.
始めから知っておった
I knew it all along.
始めからわかりきっていたことだ
It was a foregone conclusion.
始めから成功する者は少ない
Few men succeed in their first attempt.
始めから英語の先生になるつもりではなかった
It was not my original intention to become a teacher of English.
始めからしまいまで
from beginning to end―from first to last―from start to finish
彼の話は始めからしまいまで嘘だ
His story is false from beginning to end.
彼は始めからしまいまで忠義を立て通した
He remained faithful from first to last.
この本は始めからしまいまで読んだ
I have read the book from cover to cover―from tile to colophon―I have read through the book.

content: 6. (=として) from... downward

content.content: 校長を始めとして皆休みたいのだ
Everybody, from the principal downward, wishes to have a holiday.
上ご一人を始めとして下万民に至るまで義務の無い者は無い
From the Emperor down to the millions, everybody has his or her duty to perform.
ご両親始め皆様お変りありませんか
Are your parents and everybody else well?

content:
〈副〉
1. First; in the first place; in the beginning

content.content: 始め神天地を造り給う
In the beginning, God made the heaven and the earth.
始め会話を学んでそれから読書を学ぶがよい
You ought to learn conversation first, and then reading.
誰が初め大統領に選ばれたか
Who was first elected president?―Who was the first to be elected president?
初め来たのは誰か
Who came first of all?―Who was the first to come?
初めどんな本を読んだらよいでしょうか
What sort of books shall I read in the first place?
彼の失敗は今度が初めではない
This is not the first time he has failed.［注意］「始め」を動詞に訳すことあり、例えば
始め人を欺き欺きするとしまいには己を欺くようになる
One who begins by deceiving others, will end by deceiving himself.
始め要らない物を買い買いするとしまいには要る物までも売るようになる
If you begin by buying what you do not need, you end by selling what need.
東京を始め各地方に
in Tokyo and other places

content:
はじめ〔始め、初め〕
〈名〉
1. The beginning (of the month); the commencement (of the term); the outset (of one's studies); the outbreak (of the war); the start (of one's career); the dawn (of reason); the origin (of things); the opening (of a season); the inception (of a movement); the initiation (of a reform); the inauguration (of a policy); the early part (of a century, etc.)

content.content: 校長を始めとして皆休みたいのだ

content:
〈副〉
1. First; in the first place; in the beginning

content.content: 始め神天地を造り給う
In the beginning, God made the heaven and the earth.
始め会話を学んでそれから読書を学ぶがよい
You ought to learn conversation first, and then reading.
誰が初め大統領に選ばれたか

初めどんな本を読んだらよいでしょうか
What sort of books shall I read in the first place?
彼の失敗は今度が初めではない
This is not the first time he has failed.［注意］「始め」を動詞に訳すことあり、例えば
始め人を欺き欺きするとしまいには己を欺くようになる

始め要らない物を買い買いするとしまいには要る物までも売るようになる
